VF 500 - 700 möh

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Once again upper layers seem to be improving, faceted layers that were present mid snowpack seem to be starting to show some rounding, even on this almost due north aspect, but ground layer is still very scary. This pit showed a layer from the ground up to 50cm comprised of faceted crystals up to 3mm, devolving into full on cupped depth hoar up to 5mm right above ground. This layer did propagate at 21 in an ECT. Once again a low risk, high consequence scenario. This area did not show too much in terms of reactive wind slabs but with the incoming snow and wind, that could change. While the ground layer is getting deep enough to be a tough skier trigger, a wind slab breaking out higher could certainly make it react, causing an almost 1.5 meter deep slab, sliding to ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HS was much deeper in this pit than it was in most of Teepee Basin. Able to get propagation with the ECT at 46 cm with three additional stout blows after 30 taps.
Mod W winds and wind-loading in more exposed locations.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche: North Ogden Divide, 1:15pm, 7200', South Aspect, 30 degree slope, L-AS-R1/D1-I, approximately 7" deep by 15' wide by 100' long Another natural point slide was identified in close proximity on the same aspect slightly lower aspect. Both slides slid on the new snow interface rain crust from rain event on Thursday 20190117

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche. Unsure if sled triggered or not. It broke at 122.5 cm. The facets were hard to find. This snowpack (at the crown) was much deeper than one nearby (125cm). I think it gets some wind drifting along the road. Just 100yds up the road are commonly found drifts.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug w Logan DeMarcus. Previous wind loading in some areas, but the pit was in a protected location. This was one of the thinner/weaker spots we found. The problem layer of near-surface facets was not present in another pit we dug at higher elevation and more westerly aspect.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Grant Garman and Danielle Roy.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; Instability rapidly rising
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Storm began at 05:00 and deposited 13cm of 7% density so far. Winds are just beginning to shift to NW and snowfall rates are beginning to pick up. Stability in this zone seems far better than others at both similar elevations and aspects. Clearly the low elevations have less scary facets near the ground. Still not ready to trust this type of structure on slope angle above 35 degrees?

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, widespread
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile of skier triggered avalanche. It broke at 61 cm. Profile recorded in between the two tracks that entered the avalanche. The second skier triggered the slide. Aspect ranged from E to ENE and maybe a touch of NE. Slope angle where tracks entered the crown was 32 deg. There was a short rollover (maybe 50-100 ft) vertical that was 37 degrees. Collapsing was observed the day of the avalanche and the following day.

Collapsing, widespread; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
This area collapsed when we approached. This settling and energy release may account for why we did not get any ECT results at 42cm.
Some moderate NW gusts with some transport at pit. Looking above treeline, we observed moderate to strong ~NW winds and continuous snow transport towards the ~SE.
The following measurements were taken every ~3 meters, contouring the slope from South to North across the Alison Clay runout at 35.34438, -111.69169, at 10,750'. 95,87,94,63,58,67,62,66,48,56,57,56,70,73,71,97,57,108,99 = 72.8cm average snow depth.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Unsure how to score the ECT at 95 cm. It initially broke under the shovel around 7 taps. Subsequent taps caused it to propagate. Probably this is an ECTN, but it caught my attention and I wasn't going to ignore the fact that it seemed to want to propagate. The layer of snow from 95 to 100 cm was mostly broken new snow particles but they did have some faceting.

Collapsing, widespread; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Layers of concern include SH, NSF above pseudo-slab, and obvious DH below crust. Crust, although thick and P+ hardness, appears to be faceting and fails audibly with skier weight. Crust variable in thickness and distribution, see additional obs from today.

Pit dug in a Ski Area

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Still a relatively shallow snowpack, the recent warm temps seem to have helped the upper layers, but basal facets are still present, and more concerning, they actually propagated in an ECT in this pit, albeit with a good bit of force and a very poor quality shear. Overall things seem to be improving, but still a very questionable, very weak incohesive layer right above ground in our snowpack.

This is a practice pit for CMC Leadville Avalanche Snow Science program
Overall very weak and gutless, skiing on tails to avoid obstacles through the forest, difficult trailbreaking off the track. Dry forecast with cold temps over the next week won't help this snowpack.

User.name: Leslie Crawley

Location.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
Location.name: Rhino's trees

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Location is 100-mtrs from treeline on talus field approach to Lake Fork Peak. Multiple large natural avalanches observed from distance, occurred past 12-hours in upper Wilderness Bowl, SE of Kachina Peak.
PST, and ECT results repeatable and not showing propagation in storm slab. DH quiet giant produced large collapse while entering open area.
not much wind effect at this elevation, 100' higher we found moderatly fresh windslabs that were fairly tender to stuborn depending on thickness.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. 3.1. lumimyräkän aikana kaakosta luoteeseen päin liikkunut lumi oli suurimmaksi osaksi kadonnut jonnekin alemmaksi metsiin. Kellostapulilla tuulet olivat vieneet lumet suurimmaksi osaksi pois. Profiili satulan kohdalta. ITL vesiarvotesti 1 putki/25 cm/80.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack was much deeper with better structure than a pit we dug later in the day on a S-facing slope on Scotch Bonnet

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Site seems to have been consistently receiving extra snow from wind loading through season due to deeper depth than other areas at same elevation and aspect.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Big plumes of snow blowing off of the tops of the big exposed Peaks like South Bruin we witnessed repeated large plumes of snow heading North from the South wind gusts. Windy day, and fairly warm...we saw rollerballs while finishing up our pit in the afternoon on a due South aspect of Diamond Ridge above Deep Lake, just NE from our pit.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Protected lee slope TL/BTL.
This pit was dug on a clearly wind loaded slope. Other areas of the same elevation had HS around 86cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area
Collapsing, localized
Collapsing, localized
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug below natural avalanche that hit the road yesterday. I estimated that the avalanche broke below the crust at 40 cm. It may be a rime crust. Overall the snowpack was very warm and seemed damp. Temperature profile shows warm snow. It seems reasonably stable because it is so warm and damp.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; Instability rapidly rising
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Accident investigation of cornice fall/ persistent slab burial that occurred on 1/5/19. Due to overhead hazard concerns, pit was dug 450 away from the crown. The snowpack here is relatively uniform, whereas the location of the avalanche was in very steep, rocky terrain with more variable snow depths. The 35 cm of new snow in the upper snowpack accumulated after the time of the incident.
Convex in rolling terrain, exposed near alpine.

Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Instability rapidly rising
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observers: Greg McFadden, Steve Schreiber. CAIC reports High Danger rating at all elevations. Weather was quite blustery in the early morning making observations difficult until midday. Significant wind slab is forming in exposed terrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snow profile taken in location near Avalanche from 20181230

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpit location is partially sheltered by whitebark pine from both the sun and the wind. 200' vertical higher, and the wind effect/ avalanche hazard was more substantial. Observed one recent slab avalanche on an adjacent NW facing slope (a windslab about 8" deep and 20' wide).
Wind Dir at site VAR. Sno Blo L SW.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: ; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug in thinner part of crown roughly above where slide triggered. Crown face height varied noticeably within 20 m of profile site - 1 to 4+ ft. Basal DH thinner a few feet away. In profile, crust @ 28 was bed surface, but could easily have been FC below elsewhere. Time and conditions (winds) prevented more detailed profile.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 30-40 cm of new storm snow. This snow was being wind transported. New storm snow fell on weak sugary faceted snow.

User.name: Momchil Panayotov
User.affil: University of Forestry; Bulgarian extreme and freeskiing association (BEFSA)

Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Small intermittent shrubs at base of pit breaking up basal facet layer. No rain here. 50 - 75 cm layer may have been weak layer for yesterday's avalanches at higher elevations. Lacking a slab here, no wind load, not enough new snow.
Probably rained on 18 cm to 30 cm layer before it switched to snow. Also thinking pack was out of inversion at times, with warm air temperatures. Temp estimated.
